title.narrative: END VIOLENCE

description.narrative: Families increased their knowledge about the right to good treatment and the prevention of abuse, exploitation, and other forms of violence, including GBV, in homes, schools and communities, which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid), Violence, Exploitation And Abuse. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, UNICEF will have contributed to ensuring that children, adolescents and families more disadvantages from the country's priority municipalities have access to improved programmes and services for the care of victims of violence, including gender-based violence, promoting a culture of peace and good treatment, and the timely registration.

sector.narrative: Adolescents participating in or leading civic engagement initiatives (including in humanitarian settings)
Ending violence against women and girls
Parent/caregiver education and programmes on violence, exploitation and abuse - across the life cycle
Services to prevent or respond to violence, exploitation and abuse
Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Families increased their knowledge about the right to good treatment and the prevention of abuse, exploitation, and other forms of violence, including GBV, in homes, schools and communities

description.narrative: During the reporting year with UNICEF support, 74,861 people (46,414 women and girls; 28,447 men and boys) participated in awareness sessions and 6,801 (4,100 female and 2,701 male) were trained on prevention and response to violence against children, exploitation, abuse and neglect including gender-based violence. 6,223 caregivers (4,947 female and 1,276 male) increased their positive parenting skills and a Protocol to prevent and reduce violence among peers in schools was finalized and diseeminated. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:10/02/2020

title.narrative: Number of UNICEF-targeted women, girls and boys provided with risk mitigation, prevention or response interventions to address gender-based violence through UNICEF-supported programmes in the reporting year [COVID]

baseline.value: 11% identifica que el derecho al buen trato sifgnifica abstenerse de gritar, golpear y humillar, y conoce las instancias de denuncia

Data is being processed on the percentage of students and adults who understand that the right to good treatment means abstaining from shouting, beating and humiliating, as well as to know where to go. • Specifically, in the municipality Atures of the St

title.narrative: Number of people who participate in social and behavior change communication interventions promoting elimination of VAC through UNICEF programmes

baseline.value: 11% identify that the right to good treatment means refraining from shouting, hitting and humiliating; and knows the institutions for to do denunciation; 78% of caregivers are willing to use physical punishment; 41% of caregivers use the scream as a disciplinary measure

target.value: 2018:At least 2,000 children and adolescents, their teachers and families in 10 educational communities in prioritized municipalities (Distrito Capital, Sucre, Chacao, Zamora, Plaza, Lander, Los Salias, Guaicaipuro, Valencia, Libertador) know that the violence has no justification, they know where to go and they decrease the disposition and use of physical or humiliating punishment practices towards children and adolescents.
